description: Uncertain. First attested in the 1560s.; possibly an ancient unrecorded word ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *bu, but in any case likely imitative of kissing. Compare Welsh bus (“kiss, lip”) (may have influenced English), Persian بوس‎ (bus, “kiss”) and Latin basium (“kiss”).

verbs.description: buss (third-person singular simple present busses, present participle bussing, simple past and past participle bussed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, now often poetic or dialectal) To kiss (either literally or figuratively).
examples: As the repatriated explorer dodges down to buss the earth […] he is so thoroughly caught up in the rhapsody of the moment that he fails to take into account the traffic behind him.
In the faint glow of a single blue bulb hanging from a clothesline they bussed and fondled.

entries.meaning: A herring buss, a type of shallow-keeled Dutch fishing boat used especially for herring fishing.

examples: We will back the machine in which we make our daily peregrination from the top of Oxford-street to the city, against any buss on the road, whether it be for the gaudiness of its exterior, the perfect simplicity of its interior, or the native coolness of its cad.
